issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement refers to the class as 'Course', while the surrounding text and code artifacts (template and solution) refer to it as 'Lecture'. This inconsistency could confuse students about the correct class name, potentially leading them to implement the wrong name and encounter compilation errors when trying to match the template code.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML diagram in the problem statement to use 'Lecture' as the class name instead of 'Course' to ensure consistency across all artifacts and prevent student confusion.

issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement refers to the main class as 'Course', while the exercise description and both the template and solution repositories use 'Lecture' for the same conceptual entity. This discrepancy could lead students to mistakenly believe they need to implement a 'Course' class instead of 'Lecture', creating confusion in mapping requirements to code.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML diagram in the problem statement to change the class name from 'Course' to 'Lecture' to ensure consistent naming across all artifacts and reduce cognitive mapping barriers for students.
